question: When should I train an AI module vs use the lorebook?
answer:
Module is for theme, writing style and pace, they are quite bad at retaining knowledge.
This is where Lorebook enters the picture. Lorebook is basically a way to select information to be added to the context depending on what is already there, like putting a character attributes.
They are very different and can be used in synergy.

question: Did NAI improve/dumb down the model?
answer:
All updates to the model are reported in #announcements. However, generative AI models are governed by randomness, meaning, "some days seem better than others".

The human brain is prone to perceive meaning in random information. You can read more about it here <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apophenia>

question: What happened with AI dungeon?
answer:
sort of short version:
It was one the first available publicly available apps using gpt-3, using it for a text-adventure thing. The implementation of dungeon AI was laughably incompetent in many ways.
The introduction of a content filter frustrated many users enough to leave for the early beta of this service. Novel AI might not have been this successful if dungeon AI wouldn't have screwed up so badly.

If you really want to read more about it, it was here is an opinionated summary:
<https://rentry.co/remember-what-they-took-from-you>

question: What would I use if I want the AI to remember the personality of a character?
answer:
using the mind or mental attribute in their lorebook

(copied straight from lord zaltys)
`Mental:` got trained on longer descriptions, so it's better when outputting randomly generated characters. So basically, the difference in random generation: 
```Mental: Zak is smart, determined, and resourceful. He has the ability to come up with quick plans for most problems, and a high tolerance for stress.```
```Mind: Impulsive, impatient, curious, innocent```
Mental is more of a profile, Mind is a list.

question: [ info ] my understanding of embeddings and modules
answer:
Imagine having millions of ideas or concepts in your mind, but only having *words* for 1000 of them.
The tokenizer having 50k tokens is kinda like that.

Since each token is turned into an embedding (technically a list of numbers), you have more freedom for creating concepts and ideas, than you do with those 50k tokens, which each corresponding to a very specific list of numbers.

And that's why the module trainer can find 20 embeddings that capture the training data better than text could have captured it. (it has more freedom)
